Gaussian Mixture Model:ðŸ”—

The Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) is a probabilistic model used for clustering and density estimation. It assumes that the data is generated from a mixture of several Gaussian distributions.

Core Principle of GMM:ðŸ”—

The core principle behind the Gaussian Mixture Model is that data is composed of hidden or latent groups, and each group can be represented by a Gaussian distribution (defined by its mean and covariance). The "mixture" in the name reflects the fact that the model captures the overall data distribution as a combination (or mixture) of these Gaussian distributions.

Components of GMM:ðŸ”—

  1. Mixture Components: These are the individual Gaussian distributions. Each component is parameterized by:

    • Mean (Î¼\muÎ¼): The center of the distribution.
    • Covariance (Î£\SigmaÎ£): Describes the shape and orientation of the distribution.
    • Weight (Ï€\piÏ€): Represents the proportion of the overall dataset that this Gaussian component accounts for.

  2. Expectation-Maximization (EM): This is the algorithm commonly used to estimate the parameters (mean, covariance, and weight) of the Gaussian components. EM is an iterative process that alternates between:

    • Expectation Step: Assigns a probability to each data point of belonging to each Gaussian component.
    • Maximization Step: Updates the parameters of the Gaussian distributions based on the probabilities computed in the expectation step.

Example:ðŸ”—

Imagine you have height data for a group of adults and children combined, but you don't know which data point belongs to an adult and which one to a child.

If you plot this data on a histogram, you might see two peaks â€“ one corresponding to the average height of children and another to the average height of adults.

By just observing the data, it's clear there are two groups, but it's challenging to determine the exact boundary between them. This is where GMM comes in.

Using GMM, you can model the data as a mixture of two Gaussian distributions:

  1. One Gaussian might have its mean centered around the average height of children with a certain variance.
  2. The other Gaussian might have its mean centered around the average height of adults with a different variance.

GMM, through the EM algorithm, will try to find the parameters (means, variances, and weights) of these two Gaussians that best explain the observed data.

Once the model converges, you can use it to:

  1. Cluster: Assign each data point to either the "children" or "adults" group based on which Gaussian it most likely belongs to.
  2. Density Estimation: Understand the underlying probability distribution of the data.

The Gaussian Mixture Model provides a flexible, probabilistic approach to clustering and density estimation by representing data as a combination of multiple Gaussian distributions.

During the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm, the aim is to maximize this log-likelihood. The higher the log-likelihood, the better the GMM parameters (Ï€k\pi_kÏ€kâ€‹, Î¼k\mu_kÎ¼kâ€‹, Î£k\Sigma_kÎ£kâ€‹) explain the observed data.

However, if you were to define a loss as the negative log-likelihood, then you would minimize that loss.

frontmatter.summary: Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) is a probabilistic model that represents data using a combination of multiple Gaussian distributions.
